Download the free FEMA app (available in English and Spanish) to receive emergency alerts and real-time safety notifications, emergency preparedness tips, and disaster resources. Stay safe and take care of each other!

If you are a person with disabilities, you may need to take additional steps to plan for the needs of yourself and your service animal if you have one. Visit https://ready.gov/floods to learn how to stay safe before, during, and after a flood.

Stay out of floodwater. Standing water may be electrically charged from underground or downed power lines or contain hazards such as human and livestock waste, dangerous debris, contaminants that can lead to illness, or wild or stray animals.

Don’t drive through floodwaters: Almost half of all flash flood deaths happen in vehicles. When in your car, look out for flooding in low-lying areas at bridges and at highway dips. As little as 6 inches of water may cause you to lose control of your vehicle.
Use a generator safely. Never use a generator inside a home, basement, shed, or garage even if doors and windows are open.
Use only flashlights or battery-powered lanterns for emergency lighting. NEVER use candles during a blackout or power outage due to the extreme risk of fire.
Evacuate if told to do so. If you go to a community or group shelter, remember to follow the latest local recommendations.
Gather supplies for your entire household now, including medication, disinfectant supplies, face masks, and pet supplies. After a hurricane, you may not have access to them.
